Title: Parents and numeracy
Source title: International Journal of Scientific and Technology Research
Affiliations: Education Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hartono, M., Education Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This research is a part of the partnership program between Bina Nusantara University and INOVASI. INOVASI (Inovasi untuk Anak Sekolah Indonesia) is an educational partnership between Indonesia and Australia government that is aimed to find and understand ways to improve student learning outcomes in primary education – especially those related with literacy, numeracy, and inclusive education. This partnership program lasts for 12 months, in 2018-2019. The focus of this program is numeracy. The purpose of this study is 1) to find out whether there are differences in numeracy abilities of parents before the research is conducted and as tricky as research, and 2) to find out whether there are differences in the average numeracy ability of elementary school parents in Sumenep Regency. The population of this study was 180 parents of students taken from 3 elementary schools and 3 MIs. The sample in the study was 90 parents from 3 elementary schools. This research is quantitative. Data analysis was per formed on the results of the Pre-Test and Post-Test. Data were processed using SPSS 22.0. The analysis test conducted was Paired T-Test and Anova Test. The conclusions of this research are: 1) there are differences in numeracy abilities of parents before and after training; 2) There is no difference in the average Pre Test results between three groups of parents from 3 different elementary schools, but there are differences in the average Pre Test results between the thr ee groups of respondents who come from 3 different elementary schools; 3) There is no difference in the average Pre Test and Post Test results between the four groups of respondents based on age classification; and 4) There is no difference in the average Pre Test and Post Test result s between the five groups of respondents based on their educational background. © IJSTR 2019.
References: Đurišić, M., Bunijevac, M., (2017) Parental Involvement as a Important Factor for Successful Education Vključevanje staršev Kot Pomemben Dejavnik uspešnega, 7, pp. 137-153. , izobraževanja; Hoover-Dempsey, K.V., Battiato, A.C., Walker, J.M.T., Reed, R.P., Dejong, J.M., Jones, K.P., (2001) Parental Involvement in Homework, , (July 2014); Jay, T., Rose, J., Simmons, B., Finding “Mathematics”: Parents Questioning School-Centered Approaches to Involvement in Children’s Mathematics Learning, 27 (1), pp. 201-230; Kus, M., Numeracy, 27 (2), pp. 58-62; Melhuish, E.C., Phan, M.B., Sammons, P., Siraj-Blatchford, I., Taggart, B., (2008) Effects of the Home Learning Environment and Preschool Center Experience upon Literacy and Numeracy Development in Early Primary School, 64 (1), pp. 95-114; Ntekane, A., (2018) Parental Involvement in Education, , https://doi.org/10.13140/RG.2.2.36330.21440; Stephens, M., (2014) Numeracy in Practice: Teaching, Learning and Using Mathematics

Title: The effectiveness of supervision model based on professional mathematics teacher’s competency: A case study in senior high school
Source title: International Journal of Scientific and Technology Research
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hartono, M., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Oktriono, K., Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: The study aims to provide an effectiveness supervision model based on professional mathematics teachers’ competency in senior high school level. Mathematics teacher’s skills in senior high school encountered assorted defiance. It is required to be unravelling and then progressing. One endeavor to intensify the teachers’ competencies is by undertaking supervision. Supervision model, based on professional mathematics teachers’ competency, is a model that effectively increases the professional skills of mathematics teachers in senior high school. The study implemented a qualitative-based research approach, designed, and administered in Pekalongan City, Indonesia. Data collection included interviews, questionnaires, observation, and documentation. The validity of data is tested based on credibility, transferability, dependability, and conformability. The model developed is validated using the Delphi technique to obtain the final model. The practical implications of the findings in this study pose as the reference to create policies for teachers and a fundamental reference to construct another theory. The theoretical implications strengthened the component in clinical supervision. The finding of this supervision model emphasized that it anticipated the constraints found in previous studies. The data on the effectiveness of the model exhibited that 97.1% support the research finding. Therefore, it entailed the appropriate supervision model. © IJSTR 2019.
Author Keywords: Effectiveness; High school; Mathematics teacher; Model; Professional competencies; Supervision; Teacher
Funding Text 1: This work was supported by Bina Nusantara University.

Authors: Hartono M., Yulianto B., Santoso A.G., Raya C.L., Adhyatmoko K.N., Candramata M.A.
Title: Educational mathematics game for elementary students
Source title: Proceedings of 2017 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2017
Affiliations: Primary Teacher Education Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hartono, M., Primary Teacher Education Department, Faculty of Humanities, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Yulianto, B., Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Santoso, A.G., Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Raya, C.L., Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Adhyatmoko, K.N., Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Candramata, M.A., Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of this research is to develop educational mathematics game for elementary students. This game will be made to be played in a personal computer (PC). The pictures used are 2D pictures with 2D animation and audio to attract students to play the game and learn mathematics. There are 4 mini games which will be developed based on the previous research. The data collection methods used were questionnaires, literature studies, interviews, and game trials. Results show that students prefer to learn mathematics while playing game. This game has been tested by primary students and runs smoothly. The materials delivered by the game are also easily understood by students. At the end of this research, it is expected that this educational mathematics game will become an alternative media which will complement the conventional learning method. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: elementary students; games education; mathematics educational game
Index Keywords: Animation; Computer games; Information management; Personal computers; Surveys; 2D animation; Data collection method; Educational game; Elementary students; Learning methods; Literature studies; Mathematics games; Students

Authors: Hartono M., Candramata M.A., Adhyatmoko K.N., Yulianto B.
Title: Math Education Game for primary school
Source title: Proceedings of 2016 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2016
Affiliations: Primary Teacher Education, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hartono, M., Primary Teacher Education, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Candramata, M.A., Primary Teacher Education, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Adhyatmoko, K.N., Primary Teacher Education, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Yulianto, B., Primary Teacher Education, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The purpose of this research is to present a math education game as an alternative teaching method for students studying mathematics. The game is set to be released on personal computers (PC). The art of the game is set as 2D cartoon art. There will be 4 teaching methods that will help students learn mathematics in the game in the form of mini games. Each of these methods is the result of a previous research on math education for children. To date, the current development only covers 2 of 4 mini games. Questionnaire, literature study, and expert opinions are used as the data collection method. The Object Oriented approach, particularly the Inheritance Concept is used as the programming method. At the moment, a prototype education game code named Binus Math Education Game (B-Meg) is ready to be deployed. This particular education game is expected to provide an alternative and more innovative teaching method for mathematics in elementary school, or better, replace the existing conventional teaching method. © 2016 IEEE.
Author Keywords: B-Meg; Education Game; Math; Teaching Method
Index Keywords: Computer games; Information management; Object oriented programming; Personal computers; Students; Teaching; Data collection method; Education game; Elementary schools; Innovative teaching; Literature studies; Math; Object oriented approach; Teaching methods; Education

Authors: Wonowidjojo G., Hartono M.S., Frendy, Suhartono D., Asmani A.B.
Title: Automated essay scoring by combining syntactically enhanced latent semantic analysis and coreference resolution
Source title: 2016 6th International Workshop on Computer Science and Engineering, WCSE 2016
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; English Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Wonowidjojo, G., Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Hartono, M.S., Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Frendy, Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Suhartono, D., Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Asmani, A.B., English Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The objective of this research is to measure how much syntactic information (in the form of word order) and Coreference Resolution affect the result of Automated Essay Scoring (AES) using Latent Semantic Analysis (LSA). To incorporate the syntactic information, Syntactically Enhanced LSA (SELSA) is used, whilst Stanford CoreNLP Natural Language Processing Toolkit is used for the Coreference Resolution. To evaluate the results, we calculate the average absolute difference between the system score and human score for each essay. Based on the results, we can conclude that syntactic information, when combined with Coreference Resolution, do not have higher correlation to human score than LSA (an average absolute difference of 0.15748 as opposed to LSA's 0.12597). But interestingly, the two techniques work better when they are used together, rather than when they are used separately. We also develop a new algorithm to calculate the scores, with a better average absolute difference, which is as high as 0.08969.
Author Keywords: Automated essay scoring; Coreference resolution; Syntactically enhanced latent semantic analysis; Word order
Index Keywords: Automation; Semantics; Syntactics; Absolute difference; Automated essay scoring; Co-reference resolutions; Latent Semantic Analysis; NAtural language processing; Stanford; Syntactic information; Word orders; Natural language processing systems
